<image>
What is wrong with this cassava plant? Analyze the symptoms and identify the specific disease affecting it.

The cassava leaf in the image displays clear symptoms of disease progression, starting with yellowing of the upper portions that transitions to dark reddish-brown necrotic areas in the lower parts of the leaf. The affected areas show distinct angular brown patches with clearly defined margins between healthy and diseased tissue. There's a noticeable pattern of dark brown to black discoloration along the leaf veins, particularly visible where the yellowing transitions to the brown areas. The texture of the severely affected brown portions appears dry and papery, with the tissue appearing collapsed and dead. The leaf margins also show extensive browning, and the disease appears to be progressing from the leaf edges inward as well as along the veins, creating the characteristic angular patterns of infection rather than circular lesions.

This cassava plant is infected with Cassava Bacterial Blight (CBB), caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. manihotis. The symptoms exhibited in the image—including the angular brown necrotic areas, yellowing margins, vein-associated dark discoloration, and the dry papery texture of dead tissue—are all diagnostic characteristics of this bacterial disease. CBB is a serious bacterial disease of cassava that can cause significant yield losses in affected fields if not properly managed.

<image>
Please diagnose the disease affecting this cassava plant. What symptoms do you observe, and what is your conclusion?

The cassava leaves in the image display distinctive symptoms characterized by an overall yellowing of the leaf tissue, which appears as a bright yellow-green coloration across the entire leaf surface. Scattered across this yellow background are numerous dark green to olive-brown angular spots with irregular margins. These spots are distributed throughout the leaf blade, particularly concentrated in the middle portions. Some of the leaf edges and tips show signs of browning and appear slightly crisp and papery in texture. The leaf veins remain more prominently green in some areas, creating a contrast with the surrounding yellowed tissue. The angular nature of the spots, their distribution pattern along veins, and the comprehensive yellowing of the leaves are characteristic visual features of bacterial infection in cassava.

This cassava plant is affected by Cassava Bacterial Blight (CBB), caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. manihotis. The systematic yellowing of leaves combined with the angular dark green-brown spots are classic symptoms of this bacterial disease. CBB is a serious bacterial pathogen of cassava that typically begins with these distinctive leaf symptoms before potentially progressing to systemic infection that can cause wilting, dieback, and yield loss if left untreated. The observed pattern of infection with its characteristic angular lesions and yellowing confirms the diagnosis of Cassava Bacterial Blight.

<image>
Please examine this cassava plant and identify the disease. Describe the symptoms you observe and provide your diagnosis with reasoning.

The cassava leaves in the image display multiple distinctive symptoms of disease. I observe yellowing (chlorosis) of the entire leaf surface, with the leaf tissue turning a pale yellow-green color rather than the normal deep green. There are scattered dark brown to black angular spots visible across the leaf surface, particularly noticeable against the yellowed background. These angular spots appear to follow the vein patterns in several areas. The leaf margins show browning and appear dry with a papery texture, indicating necrosis of tissue. Some leaves have a downward drooping posture, suggesting wilting. The disease appears to have affected the entire leaf whorl, with symptoms progressing from initial spotting to widespread yellowing. The angular nature of the spots is particularly significant, as they appear constrained by the leaf veins, creating geometric patterns rather than circular lesions.

This cassava plant is infected with Cassava Bacterial Blight (CBB), caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. manihotis. The diagnostic features include the angular dark brown spots with yellow margins, the systematic yellowing of the entire leaf, and the progression of symptoms across the leaf whorl. This bacterial disease is one of the most serious diseases affecting cassava production worldwide, causing yield losses of up to 80% in severely affected plants. The bacteria typically enter through stomata or wounds and spread systemically through the vascular system, explaining the pattern of symptoms observed in this specimen.

Identify the disease affecting this cassava plant. Please analyze the visual symptoms and explain how you reached your diagnosis.

Looking at this cassava leaf, I observe distinct reddish-brown angular spots scattered across the green leaf surface. These spots appear to have a dry, somewhat papery texture and have clearly defined edges that follow the leaf's venation pattern. The spots have a distinctive angular shape rather than being circular, which is characteristic of bacterial infections that are limited by leaf veins. Some spots show a slight yellowish margin transitioning between the healthy green tissue and the necrotic brown areas. The infection appears to be in various stages, with some lesions being smaller and others having coalesced into larger patches. The surrounding leaf tissue is still green, though some yellowing is visible in areas adjacent to the infection sites, suggesting the disease is actively progressing.

This cassava plant is infected with Cassava Bacterial Blight (CBB), caused by the bacterium Xanthomonas axonopodis pv. manihotis. The angular shape of the lesions, their reddish-brown color, and their distribution pattern along the leaf veins are classic symptoms of this bacterial disease. CBB is a significant cassava pathogen that typically begins with these characteristic angular leaf spots before potentially progressing to systemic infection that can cause leaf wilting, stem die-back, and exudation of bacterial ooze from infected stems in severe cases.

<image>
What is wrong with this cassava plant? Analyze the symptoms and identify the specific disease affecting it.

The cassava leaves in the image display distinctive circular lesions with pinkish-brown centers surrounded by yellowish halos. These spots appear somewhat sunken and are distributed across the leaf surface. The lesions are clearly defined with a consistent circular shape, measuring approximately 3-5mm in diameter. The primary leaf tissue remains green, but there are multiple isolated lesions scattered throughout. The reddish-pink leaf veins remain intact and do not show discoloration along their length. The texture of the affected areas appears slightly different from the healthy tissue, but doesn't show the papery or severely necrotic characteristics typical of bacterial infections.

Based on the visual symptoms observed in this image, this cassava plant is affected by Cassava Brown Leaf Spot (Cercosporidium henningsii), not Cassava Bacterial Blight. The circular, pinkish-brown spots with yellowish margins are characteristic of this fungal disease. Cercosporidium henningsii causes these distinctive round lesions that remain isolated rather than spreading along veins or forming angular spots typical of bacterial infections. The disease typically affects lower, older leaves first but can spread upward through the plant under favorable conditions.

<image>
Can you identify the disease on this cassava plant? Please provide a detailed analysis of the symptoms and your final diagnosis.

The cassava leaves in the image exhibit distinctive visual symptoms consistent with viral infection. The most noticeable feature is the irregular mosaic pattern of light green and dark green areas across the leaf surfaces, particularly evident in the central plant. Several leaves show a mottled appearance with patchy, pale yellowish-green regions interspersed with normal green tissue, creating a distinct mosaic effect. There is also visible leaf distortion and mild curling, especially at the leaf margins, giving them an abnormal shape compared to healthy cassava leaves. The affected leaves appear slightly reduced in size with some narrowing. Some leaves display a roughened surface texture where the discoloration is most severe. These mosaic patterns are not uniform across the plant but appear in an irregular distribution, with some leaves showing more intense symptoms than others.

This plant is affected by Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD), caused by cassava mosaic geminiviruses (family Geminiviridae, genus Begomovirus). The irregular light/dark green mosaic pattern, yellowing mottling, leaf distortion, and reduced leaf size are hallmark symptoms of this viral disease. CMD is one of the most economically significant diseases affecting cassava production across Africa and parts of Asia, typically transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci) or through the planting of infected stem cuttings. The symptoms observed in this specimen represent the classic presentation of CMD infection in cassava plants.

This cassava plant is infected with Cassava Mosaic Disease (CMD), caused by cassava mosaic geminiviruses (family Geminiviridae, genus Begomovirus). The characteristic irregular mosaic pattern, the yellow-green mottling, and the mild leaf distortion are classic symptoms of this viral disease. CMD is one of the most economically important diseases of cassava in Africa and parts of Asia, transmitted primarily by the whitefly Bemisia tabaci and through infected cuttings used for propagation.
